conclusion: The problem involves a charged ball suspended by a string in a uniform electric field.
The ball is at rest, indicating equilibrium of forces.
There are three forces acting on the ball: gravitational force, electric force, and tension.
The tension in the string can be resolved into vertical and horizontal components.
For the ball to be at rest, the vertical component of the tension must equal the gravitational force.
The horizontal component of the tension must equal the electric force.
The tension can be expressed as \\( T = \frac{mg}{\cos \theta} \\).
Substituting the expression for tension into the horizontal equilibrium equation gives \\( mg \tan \theta = qE \\).
The electric field strength is \\(  oxed{\frac{mg \tan \theta}{q}} \\).
